comments.move_1: King's Gambit - aggressive romantic era opening
comments.move_11: White sacrifices a rook! The brilliance begins.
comments.move_18: The legendary queen sacrifice! Anderssen gives up his most powerful piece.
comments.move_21: Another piece sacrificed for the attack!
comments.move_23: Checkmate! A masterpiece of sacrificial chess. White gave up both rooks and the queen but delivered mate with minor pieces.

games.description: Perhaps the most famous chess game ever played. Anderssen sacrifices both rooks and his queen to deliver checkmate with minor pieces. A brilliant example of romantic era attacking chess.

games.description: Another Anderssen masterpiece. A game so beautiful it earned the name 'Evergreen' - its brilliance never fades with time.

comments.move_17: Checkmate with just a rook. Brilliantly economical finish.

games.description: Played at the Paris Opera while the Duke and Count were watching a performance. Morphy delivers a 17-move masterpiece, sacrificing his queen to deliver mate. A perfect example of superior development winning.

comments.move_31: Checkmate! 13-year-old Fischer defeats an International Master with one of the most famous combinations in chess history.

games.description: 13-year-old Bobby Fischer defeats International Master Donald Byrne with a stunning queen sacrifice and king hunt. Called 'Game of the Century' by Hans Kmoch. One of the greatest games ever played.
